search_results.snippet: According to food writer Sharon Tyler Herbst,[1] pico de gallo ("rooster's beak") is named thus because originally people ate it by pinching pieces between the thumb and forefinger. Besides, picar also means to chop.

search_results.snippet: Pico de gallo. In Mexican cuisine, pico de gallo (Spanish pronunciation: [piko e ao], literally beak of rooster ), also called salsa fresca, is made from chopped tomato, onion, coriander leaves, fresh serranos (jalapeos or habaneros are used as alternatives), salt, and key lime juice.
